I started playing Counter-Strike in version 1.3 and moved to 1.5 before switching to 1.6 for competitive matches. I avoided playing Source and CS:GO because their slow gameplay speed deviated from the traditional fast Counter-Strike gameplay I loved.

The new matchmaking system in Counter-Strike 2 interests me, but the gameplay experience differs substantially from what I expected. The game visuals and textures appear too refined which creates a plasticine effect that disrupts the game's visual appearance. It is an acquired visual, and not sure I enjoy the one presented here even after adapting to it.

The weapons sound design is quite poor. It's quite muffled, while the visual distinction between players and their surroundings creates difficulties when trying to detect enemies. The footstep audio is also quite reduced to the original setting, making it harder to detect opponents who are nearby. The grenades are tiny, barely visible.

The essential gameplay elements which made the classic Counter-Strike versions 1.5 and 1.6 unique have undergone significant changes, and it is very apparent. My 25 years of experience with the series made it difficult to adjust to CS2 because I needed to relearn basic gameplay mechanics which surprised me as a seasoned player. Yeah, my headshot ratio is still high, however the movement, and generally the speed, element of surprise is completely gone. It takes forever to rush a single bomb site. The models feel heavy, sluggish, even with a knife. The jumping mechanism is slower than usual.

One thing that made Counter-Strike 1.5 and 1.6 great, was the movement. You could easily navigate, with a bit of practice. In CS2 it feels like an uphill battle for no reason.

The CS2 does retain some of the Counter-Strike flair, yet it presents a completely different gameplay experience than the original versions. The main problem in ranked matches of CS2 stems from the high number of cheaters who play against legitimate players. The high number of fake and purchased accounts creates a noticeable problem which ruins the gameplay experience. These are not small number of players, this is notably every 2nd account that is in any ranked matchmaking. They either use Wallhack, or Aimbot, or a combination of the two. It's very typical. 

Although CS 1.5 and 1.6 have their own Cheater issues, these are mostly easily recognized, and people who cheat tend to get punished quickly by server ban.

I have not fully investigated Faceit but I believe cheating might still exist within this platform, unsure. The current VAC anti-cheat system fails to provide sufficient protection against cheating activities, and I've experienced this in 4/5 games I've played this week alone. It's amazing how many cheaters there are! 

I do think that the game requires dedicated servers with active administrators to manage gameplay and create a balanced competitive environment. The game shows promise but it deviates from the traditional Counter-Strike gameplay that true fans of the game know and love.

Absolute Perfection ‚Äì CS2 is More Than a Game, It‚Äôs My Life

Counter-Strike 2 isn‚Äôt just an upgrade ‚Äî it‚Äôs a revolution. From the moment I launched it, I knew this was something special. The visuals? Crisp, immersive, next-level. The smoke grenades that now dynamically flow with the air? The reimagined maps with stunning detail? The lightning-fast netcode that makes every flick shot feel just right? Valve didn‚Äôt just update a game ‚Äî they rebirthed a legacy.

I‚Äôve poured hundreds of hours into CS over the years, and CS2 feels like the game I‚Äôve always dreamed of. Whether I‚Äôm clutching out a 1v5 on Mirage, dropping a perfect flash on Dust II, or coordinating with my team in competitive, every match is pure adrenaline. The sound design is so precise I can tell an AWP shot from a scout just by the echo. The balance? Flawless. The community? Still the most intense, passionate group of players in gaming.

I play almost every day ‚Äî with friends, in ranked, in deathmatch just to warm up. CS2 has brought me closer to my squad, challenged my mind, sharpened my reflexes, and given me memories I‚Äôll never forget. That ace with the M4? The knife flick that shut down the round? Pure magic.

Thank you, Valve, for not just preserving what made Counter-Strike legendary, but for evolving it with such care and precision. This isn‚Äôt just my favorite shooter ‚Äî it‚Äôs my obsession. CS2 isn‚Äôt just worth every penny‚Ä¶ it‚Äôs priceless.

Counter-Strike 2 isn‚Äôt perfect, but let‚Äôs be honest: neither was CS:GO, and we still sank thousands of hours into it. CS2 takes the foundation we already love ‚Äî the tension of a 1v3 clutch, the deafening sound of a perfectly timed flash, the dopamine hit of an eco round win ‚Äî and brings it into a new era.

What works:

- Gunplay feels crisp. Tapping heads with the AK never gets old, and spraying still takes actual skill instead of RNG praying.

- Smokes are next-level. Dynamic, volumetric, reactive. Shooting or throwing nades through them is a game-changer. Feels like CS, but evolved.

- Source 2 glow-up. Maps are brighter, cleaner, and easier to read. Even classic Mirage feels like a fresh experience.

- Matchmaking is faster. I‚Äôm queuing with friends in minutes instead of waiting in limbo.

- Same heart-pounding clutch moments. When it‚Äôs down to you, the bomb, and 3 enemies hunting you ‚Äî nothing else in gaming compares.

What doesn‚Äôt (yet):

- Performance can dip on mid-tier rigs. Source 2 looks gorgeous, but it eats weaker PCs for breakfast.

- Some sound bugs and netcode quirks still pop up ‚Äî classic CS experience, honestly.

- The community‚Ä¶ is still the community. But that‚Äôs part of the charm, right?

At its core, CS2 is still Counter-Strike: brutal, rewarding, and endlessly replayable. It‚Äôs a free upgrade, it already feels like home, and despite the rough edges, it‚Äôs the best version of CS we‚Äôve had in years.

If you‚Äôve ever shouted ‚Äúrush B‚Äù with your friends at 3 AM, you‚Äôll feel right at home here.

This is my most played game on my steam account. The time I've spent on it I don't regret and the game is incredibly unique. That being said the overall experience is consistently disappointing. There are many design choices that are lackluster and leave the game feeling like it has much more potential, but the game will never reach the potential because it seems like the devs will add anything BUT what the community that actually dumps hours into this game wants. Season 17 is a summation of everything wrong with the games content updates and generally empty and disappointing feel of the last 5 years.

They removed CS:GO removing some of the best maps. Messing with the tick rate and not bothering to update the anti cheat system. The game is only fun sometimes because it has shadows of its former self occasionally but it will never be the same.

Good to play with at least one friend. Great atmosphere, sailing feels good. Tons of different stuff to do (and tons of achievement meters to fill) but it all ends up feeling pretty samey owing to a limited palette of threats and combat being quite janky and undercooked. PVP side feels a little dead now, recent player sightings have been 90% avoidance/ignore and 10% kill-on-sight sociopathy. "Some" (not enough) of the game is available to play without the PVP aspect, but still online, and on worse servers. The Monkey Island stuff is mainly "follow a bad online guide" type content if you want to see 100%.

Bad netcode, no tutorial for newcomers, it's as if this game was meant only for those who played this from the getgo starting from CS 1.6, so if you are new, getting into the thick of it is quite challenging. 

Very questionable firing mechanics, namely hip firing being super accurate (LMAO) as long as you stay still or crouch or, better yet, strafe and then immediately stop to get 100% accuracy within several ms is just a bs feature that should be permanently removed from the game especially given how the netcode is so bad and you see the person just running and gunning but he is actually moving-counterstrafing-standing-shooting, which makes you think that the person is just cheating. 

RNG damage on guns, for example it can take 4-5 shots to kill an armored player or 5-6 depending on the gun even if you shoot in exact same spot in the training workshop map, which IMO is stupid given how the in game counterstrafing mechanic makes you super accurate for a few ms, so should the damage be exactly the same (which never happens in real life, but so does the counter strafing - that doens't happen in real life) so the game is extremely inconsistent with its logic implementation. 

Honestly shooting at the range with real guns is far more pleasureable and easier than trying to aim in this POS of a game. I hope this game crashes and burns.

Additionally, there's a ton of cheaters who see through walls, who use aimbot, who's bullets curve around the wall, and it's like that in every other game, sometimes you get more than 1 cheater in a match. And as much as I would like to say it's a bad thing, given how s**t this game is to begin with, I hope there will be even more cheaters in this game, because the only thing that can kill this game is more cheating. 

So more cheaters in the game - the faster this game dies and hopefully people will switch to something better, meanwhile the greedy f**ks at valve will lose their money. 

So my last words/advice in this review - if you consider playing it, install all the cheats and kill this game from within as fast as possible, it's irredemable at this point, at least I will get a good laugh with all the cheaters inside this game.

The Good: A Visual and Technical Leap
The most immediate and striking difference in CS2 is its visual fidelity. The Source 2 engine has transformed the game, with stunningly detailed maps, realistic lighting, and physically-based rendering that makes weapon skins and environments pop like never before. Maps like Inferno and Anubis, which received full overhauls, are particularly impressive, showcasing a level of detail that brings them closer to modern AAA titles. Even the "touchstone" maps like Dust II, which retain their original layouts, benefit from improved lighting that enhances visibility and character readability.

Beyond the visuals, CS2 introduces several key technical innovations. The new "sub-tick" architecture is designed to make player actions like shooting and grenade throws more precise, ensuring what you see is what you get, regardless of the server's tick rate. The dynamic, volumetric smoke grenades are a game-changer. They now fill spaces naturally and can be cleared by shooting or throwing high-explosive grenades, creating new strategic possibilities and counters that were impossible in CS:GO. This change alone has forced a fundamental rethink of how players use utility.

The new Premier mode, with its Elo-based rating system and map-veto phase, is a solid step toward a more professional and rewarding competitive experience. It successfully replicates the feel of a high-stakes match, a feature that was sorely needed in CS:GO's public matchmaking.

The Mixed: A Legacy of Change
While the core gameplay is largely the same, CS2's mechanics have been a point of contention. The movement, shooting, and general "feel" of the game have been a frequent topic of debate within the community and among professional players. Some veteran players feel that the game lacks the snappy, responsive feel of CS:GO, citing issues with hit registration, peekers' advantage, and the overall "weight" of player movement. This has led to a feeling of inconsistency for those with tens of thousands of hours in the previous game.

The transition also came with a significant loss of features. Many beloved game modes from CS:GO, such as Arms Race, Danger Zone, and Retakes, were absent at launch. While some, like Arms Race, have since been re-added, the initial release felt barebones. Community server support, a cornerstone of the franchise, was also lacking for a long period, which alienated many players who enjoyed custom game modes and maps. The shorter MR12 (max 12 rounds) format for competitive matches is also a divisive change, with some appreciating the faster pace while others miss the strategic depth of the longer MR15 format.

The Bad: Performance and Cheating
CS2's biggest Achilles' heel has been its technical performance. Unlike CS:GO, which could run on a wide range of hardware, CS2 is significantly more demanding. Players, including professionals, have reported frequent performance issues, stuttering, and frame drops, even on high-end systems. This lack of optimization has made the game less accessible and has been a major source of frustration for the player base.

The state of the anti-cheat system is another major concern. User reviews and community discussions are filled with complaints about the prevalence of cheaters, particularly at higher ranks. The community feels that Valve's anti-cheat measures are not up to the task, leading to a frustrating and unfair competitive environment that undermines the integrity of the game. This issue has led many players to abandon official matchmaking in favor of third-party platforms.

Conclusion
Counter-Strike 2 is a game with immense potential and a solid foundation. The move to Source 2 has given the franchise a much-needed visual and technical facelift, and the dynamic smoke grenades are a revolutionary change for the tactical shooter genre. However, its full release was premature. The game launched with a laundry list of missing features and critical technical problems, most notably with performance and anti-cheat. It's a game that feels like it's still in an extended beta, a beautiful shell that's waiting to be fully polished. For new players, it offers an accessible and modern entry into the Counter-Strike world. For veterans, it's a test of patience, a promise of a great game that is slowly but surely being realized.

Despite experiencing no significant updates, facing a bot crisis, and suffering from balancing issues, you can still hop in and find a surprisingly nice community. While some are genuinely nice, many are more interested in making connections than actually playing the game. The art style is reminiscent of a comic book, standing the test of time and never looking bad. The Meet the Team videos provide insight into each class's specialties and showcase the game‚Äôs goofy tone, while the SFM videos represent a beautiful art form that I hope never disappears.

It‚Äôs a laid-back game where you can chat and play in the background, sometimes a guilty pleasure, other times a time killer, but always somehow a good time.
